head.supplied: 5. 10. [189]3 ¶ Dear Baron von Mueller, ¶ ¶ I have pleasure in being able to inform you that I have just posted to Professor Krichauff's address a copy of my "British New Guinea", ¶ together with a ...

div.p: OM 65-21/1, letterbook of James Park Thomson, p. 357, John Oxley Library, State Library of Queensland, Brisbane.

I have pleasure in being able to inform you that I have just posted to Professor Krichauff's address a copy of my "British New Guinea",
Reference?
together with a few New Guinea photographs,
See also J. Thomson to M, 18 September 1893. representing typical subjects. I have not sent any letter, but left you to write full particulars to your distinguished friend.

We are all delighted at Mr Gregory's election to the position of President of the Association.
Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science. The nomination of the other candidates was simply done by our local Secretary without the consent of the majority of the members of the local Committee, & his action caused a great deal of dissatisfaction among the scientific men here. He did what he had no right to do & the defeat he met with served him right.
At the meeting of the General Council of the Association held in Adelaide on 26 September 1893, 'Mr Shirley, the local Secretary for Brisbane, said when he left that city he had been charged with the duty of proposing the election of Sir Samuel Griffith, the Chief Justice of the colony, as President. Since his arrival in Adelaide he had received a telegram from the Hon. A. Norton [the local Treasurer for Brisbane], stating that Sir Samuel Griffith had withdrawn, and that the Hon. A. C. Gregory. C.M.G., had consented to be nominated.' Being a member of the local Committee I did not sign the letter, but the whole movement had my full sympathy & I helped very materially to bring about its success.
